pullRequest.body:
The aim of this PR is to show that `gaussSum Ï‡ e`, for `Ï‡` a Dirichlet character mod `N` and `e` an additive character mod `N`, is zero if `Ï‡` is primitive but `e` is not. This will be used to prove the functional equation for Dirichlet L-series in a later PR.

Along the way we add various general-purpose lemmas about divisibility in `ZMod N` and other finite rings, and about conductors and primitivity of Dirichlet and additive characters.

---

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go

will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:

- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

nodes.body:
Thanks Michael for the review! I have updated the PR accordingly. 

In the process, I realised that I had (coincidentally) added 2 of the 3 lemmas suggested in a "TODO" note at the top of `DirichletCharacter/Basic.lean`. So I have completed the job by adding the third TODO lemma (`changeLevel_eq_one_iff`) to this PR, and removed the note.
maintainer merge
ðŸš€ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by MichaelStollBayreuth.

Thanks!

bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8913092847/job/24477904067)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8913092847/job/24477903853)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8913092847/job/24477904486)
LGTM!
LGTM!
Maybe `IsUnit.mem_nonZeroDivisors` instead to enable dot notation?

_Note to reviewers of this PR_: I removed this lemma, and the import needed to state it, because it doesn't actually do anything. The Dirichlet character `Ï‡` coerces to a function `ZMod n â†’ R` so `m` is getting coerced into `ZMod n`; and the hypotheses imply that `m` coerces to zero in `ZMod n`. So this is actually showing that `Ï‡` is periodic with period 0, which is not a useful statement. 

(Maybe `Function.Periodic (Ï‡ âˆ˜ Int.cast) m` is what was intended, but it is probably better to show that via periodicity of `Int.cast`.)

Quoting from the [Documentation style](https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/doc.html) page:
```quote
 If a doc string is a complete sentence, then it should end in a period.
```
Which I read as "a period is not required when the doc string is not a complete sentence". (But a period is certainly allowed in such a case.)

```suggestion
  exact âŸ¨Ï‡â‚‚, rfl, fun Ï‡â‚ƒ hÏ‡â‚ƒ â†¦ (changeLevel_injective hd hÏ‡â‚ƒ).symmâŸ©
```

```suggestion
`d`. (This will be used to show that Gauss sums vanish when `Ï‡` is primitive and `e` is not.) -/
```

Maybe add
```lean
lemma MulChar.map_unit (Ï‡ : MulChar R R') {a : R} (ha : IsUnit a) : IsUnit (Ï‡ a)
```
(with suitable `R` and `R'`) in `Mathlib.NumberTheory.LegendreSymbol.MulCharacter`? 
It looks like a generally useful statement.
In the course of attempting to add it, I realised someone had already done so â€“Â it's `IsUnit.map`.
I think it makes sense to have a separate lemma for this.
How does it relate to `not_isPrimitive_mulShift` below?
Good point â€“ I separated that out as a separate lemma and then forgot to update the original proof using it.
It is good to have that! I'm surprised it wasn't there already...

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(NumberTheory/DirichletCharacter): vanishing of Gauss sums when add char is imprimitive

source.title: Tracking issue for Hurwitz and Dirichlet L-series
